newsitem.title: UK: GEC bows to shareholder pressure on boardroom pay.
newsitem.headline: GEC bows to shareholder pressure on boardroom pay.

text.p: British defence and engineering giant General Electric Company has bowed to shareholder anger over a controversial pay package for its new managing director by toughening the contract's performance targets.

The company said Monday it amended the contract, under which George Simpson will now receive a huge block of stock options if GEC's share price exceeds by at least 10 percent the growth in the FTSE 100 index over a three-year period, instead of the six months previously agreed upon.
"GEC and Mr. Simpson have always envisaged that challenging performance criteria would be attached to awards made to Mr. Simpson," the group said in a brief statement.

Senior company executives met the Association of British Insurers' earlier Monday to try to head off a possible revolt at its annual meeting in four days, amid rising institutional anger that GEC was being too generous to Simpson.
GEC added that Simpson had agreed to the amendment and the criteria complied with ABI guidelines. The terms previously reflected Simpson's arrangements with his employer then.
The Times newspaper said Simpson had sought the addition of stricter performance targets to his contract.
Simpson's three year contract gives him annual pay of up to 1.5 million pounds ($2.35 million), including pension contributions, plus a complicated package of share options.
The former chief executive of Lucas Industries, who takes over at GEC from Lord Weinstock, has already been dubbed "the fattest cat of all" by British newspapers.
His controversial deal has turned up the heat in the debate about top executives' pay, sparked last year when former British Gas Chief Executive Cedric Brown was awarded a 75 percent raise.

Mounting public anger over "fat cat" salaries prompted the government to set up a committee to curb boardroom excesses. But despite guidelines set by the committee, led by Marks & Spencer Chairman Sir Richard Greenbury, executive salaries are rising.
